sect1.title: A list of the different kinds of configuration
sect1.para: These sections show the various ways of populating an application context with object definitions. It is not an exhaustive guide to all the possibilities that an object definition offers. Please refer to the section 'Object Definitions' for a complete overview of this.

sect2.title: MXML Configuration
sect2.para: For Flex based applications the MXML configuration offers a familiar environment for populating the application context with object definitions.

To start an MXML configuration file create an MXML component that extends SASObjects and you can add components to it of type Object.<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <sas:SASObjects xmlns:fx="http://ns.adobe.com/mxml/2009" xmlns:s="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/spark" xmlns:mx="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/mx" xmlns:sas="http://www.springactionscript.org/mxml/config"> <fx:Script> <![CDATA[ import com.classes.MyClass; import com.classes.MyOtherClass; ]]> </fx:Script>
<sas:Object class="{MyClass}" id="myClass"/>
<sas:Object class="{MyOtherClass}" id="myOtherClass"/>
</sas:SASObjects>
You can also add instances of objects explicitly to the configurations, these will be treated as singletons by application context.
sect2.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <sas:SASObjects xmlns:fx="http://ns.adobe.com/mxml/2009" xmlns:s="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/spark" xmlns:mx="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/mx" xmlns:sas="http://www.springactionscript.org/mxml/config"> <fx:Script> <![CDATA[ import com.classes.MyClass; import com.classes.MyOtherClass; ]]> </fx:Script>
<mx:RemoteObject id="myRemoteObject"/>
<sas:Object class="{MyClass}" id="myClass"/>
<sas:Object class="{MyOtherClass}" id="myOtherClass"/>
</sas:SASObjects>
sect2.para: These instances, of course, don't necesarrily have to be declared as MXML, they can be regular public fields as well:
sect2.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <sas:SASObjects xmlns:fx="http://ns.adobe.com/mxml/2009" xmlns:s="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/spark" xmlns:mx="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/mx" xmlns:sas="http://www.springactionscript.org/mxml/config"> <fx:Script> <![CDATA[ import com.classes.MyClass; import com.classes.MyOtherClass;
public var mySimpleClass:SimpleClass = new SimpleClass(); ]]> </fx:Script>
<mx:RemoteObject id="myRemoteObject"/>
<sas:Object class="{MyClass}" id="myClass"/>
<sas:Object class="{MyOtherClass}" id="myOtherClass"/>
</sas:SASObjects>
sect2.para: To inject an instance into the property of another instance, add a property definition like this.
sect2.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <sas:SASObjects xmlns:fx="http://ns.adobe.com/mxml/2009" xmlns:s="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/spark" xmlns:mx="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/mx" xmlns:sas="http://www.springactionscript.org/mxml/config"> <fx:Script> <![CDATA[ import com.classes.MyClass; import com.classes.MyOtherClass;
public var mySimpleClass:SimpleClass = new SimpleClass(); ]]> </fx:Script>
<mx:RemoteObject id="myRemoteObject"/>
<sas:Object class="{MyClass}" id="myClass"> <sas:Property name="remoteObject" ref="myRemoteObject"/> <sas:Property name="myOtherClassInstance" ref="{myOtherClass}"/> <sas:Property name="mySimpleClassInstance" ref="{mySimpleClass}"/> </sas:Object>
<sas:Object class="{MyOtherClass}" id="myOtherClass"/>
</sas:SASObjects>
sect2.para: Method invocations are added like this:
sect2.programlisting: <sas:Object class="{MyClass}" id="myClass"> <sas:Property name="remoteObject" ref="myRemoteObject"/> <sas:Property name="myOtherClassInstance" ref="{myOtherClass}"/> <sas:MethodInvocation name="myMethod"> <sas:Arg ref="{someOtherObject}"/> <sas:Arg value="$(externalPropertyValue)"/> </sas:MethodInvocation> </sas:Object>
sect2.para: Notice the $(externalPropertyValue) placeholder, this indicates that the value of this argument will be replaced by an external property value. Check out the section 'Using property files' for more information on this.

MXML configurations can easily be nested as well. So if a particular configuration becomes too big and its hard to get an overview, breaking it up in smaller configurations might prove helpful. In the example below it is assumed that both MXML components are in separate files:
sect2.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <sas:SASObjects xmlns:fx="http://ns.adobe.com/mxml/2009" xmlns:s="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/spark" xmlns:mx="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/mx" xmlns:sas="http://www.springactionscript.org/mxml/config" xmlns:local="*"> <fx:Script> <![CDATA[ import com.classes.MyClass; import com.classes.MyOtherClass; ]]> </fx:Script>
<local:InnerConfig id="innerConfig"/>
<sas:Object class="{MyClass}" id="myClass"> <sas:Property name="remoteObject" ref="innerConfig.myRemoteObject"/> <sas:Property name="myOtherClassInstance" ref="{myOtherClass}"/> </sas:Object>
<sas:Object class="{MyOtherClass}" id="myOtherClass"/>
</sas:SASObjects>
sect2.para:
You can set default properties for every object definition within a configuration by adding them to the main <sas:SASObjects/> element:<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <sas:SASObjects xmlns:fx="http://ns.adobe.com/mxml/2009" xmlns:s="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/spark" xmlns:mx="library://ns.adobe.com/flex/mx" xmlns:sas="http://www.springactionscript.org/mxml/config" scope="{ObjectDefinitionScope.PROTOTYPE}" skipPostProcessors="true"> <fx:Script> <![CDATA[ import com.classes.MyClass; import com.classes.MyOtherClass; ]]> </fx:Script>
<sas:Object class="{MyClass}" id="myClass"> <sas:Property name="remoteObject" ref="innerConfig.myRemoteObject"/> <sas:Property name="myOtherClassInstance" ref="{myOtherClass}"/> </sas:Object>
<sas:Object class="{MyOtherClass}" id="myOtherClass"/>
</sas:SASObjects>

sect2.title: XML Configuration
sect2.para: XML configuration gives a more flexible way of populating an application context since the XML file(s) will be loaded at runtime. Which means that without re-compiling the application it is possible to change the configuration. It also comes with a number of downsides, most important of which is the necessity to explicitly declare the classes that are defined in the XML, otherwise these classes will not get compiled into the SWF file.
Various ways of ensuring this process are described in the section 'Forcing actionscript class inclusion'.
Start with creating an XML file that contains the following namespace declaration and add <object/> elements to describe the various object definitions:
sect2.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <objects xmlns="http://www.springactionscript.org/schema/objects" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springactionscript.org/schema/objects http://www.springactionscript.org/schema/objects/spring-actionscript-objects-2.0.xsd">
<object class="com.classes.MyClass" id="myClass"/>
<object class="com.classes.myOtherClass" id="myOtherClass"/>
</objects>
sect2.para:
To inject an instance into the property of another instance, add a property definition like this.<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <objects xmlns="http://www.springactionscript.org/schema/objects" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springactionscript.org/schema/objects http://www.springactionscript.org/schema/objects/spring-actionscript-objects-2.0.xsd">
<object class="com.classes.MyClass" id="myClass"> <property name="myOtherClassInstance"> <ref>myOtherClass</ref> </property> </object>
<object class="com.classes.myOtherClass" id="myOtherClass"/>
</objects>

The <property/>, <arg/> and <constructor-arg/> elements also support the use of the 'value' and 'ref' attributes, which can lead to much more succinct configuration. When using the 'value' and 'ref'attributes, the above object definition reads like so:
sect2.programlisting: <object class="com.classes.MyClass" id="myClass"> <constructor-arg value="someString"/> <property name="myOtherClassInstance" ref="myOtherClass"/> <method-invocation name="myMethod"> <arg ref="someOtherObject"/> <arg value="${externalPropertyValue}"/> </method-invocation> </object>
sect2.para: Notice the ${externalPropertyValue} placeholder, this indicates that the value of this argument will be replaced by an external property value. Check out the section 'Using property files' for more information on this.

sect3.title: Inner objects
sect3.para: An <object/> element inside the <property/> or <constructor-arg/> elements is used to define a so-called inner object. An inner object definition does not need to have any id defined, and it is best not to even specify any id value because the id value simply will be ignored by the container.
sect3.programlisting: <object id="outer" class="..."> < instead of using a reference to a target object, simply define the target object inline > <property name="target"> <object class="com.example.Person"> < this is the inner object > <property name="name" value="Fiona Apple"/> <property name="age" value="25"/> </object> </property> </object>
sect3.para: Note that in the specific case of inner objects, the 'scope' flag and any 'id' attribute are effectively ignored. Inner objects are always anonymous and they are always scoped as prototypes. Please also note that it is not possible to inject inner objects into collaborating objects other than the enclosing object.

sect3.title: Collections
sect3.para: The <array/>, <array-collection/> ,<dictionary/> and <vector/> elements allow properties and arguments of the Actionscript collection type Array, ArrayCollection, Dictionary and Vector, respectively, to be defined and set. Be aware that the array-collection type can only be used in a Flex based application object since it is part of the framework.
sect3.programlisting:
<object id="moreComplexObject" class="example.ComplexObject"> <property name="adminEmails"> <dictionary> <entry key="administrator" value="administrator@example.org"/> <entry key="support" value="support@example.org"/> <!-- or a more verbose way of defining an entry --> <entry> <key>development</key> <value>development@example.org</value> </entry> </dictionary> </property>
<property name="someList"> <array> <value>a list element followed by a reference</value> <value><ref object="myOtherObject" /></value> </array> </property>
<!-- Only use this in a Flex based application --> <property name="someOtherList"> <array-collection> <value>a list element followed by a reference</value> <value><ref object="myOtherObject" /></value> </array-collection> </property>
<property name="vectorProperty"> <vector type="String"> <value>string1</value> <value>string2</value> <ref>stringRef</ref> <object class="String"><constructor-arg>string4</constructor-arg></object> </vector> </property>
<object id="stringRef" class="String"><constructor-arg>string3</constructor-arg></object> </object>

sect2.title: Metadata Configuration
sect2.para: In the case of a metadata based configuration there is no need for a separate config file. The source code itself will act as the configuration.
For a class to be added as a definition to the application context all you need to do is annotate it with the [Component] metadata.
Properties may be annotated with the [Property] metadata to indicate they need to be injected.

Notice the ${externalPropertyValue} placeholder, this indicates that the value of this argument will be replaced by an external property value. Check out the section 'Using property files' for more information on this.
A method invocation may be added using the [Invoke] metadata.
If the method needs to receieve any arguments they maybe added as metadata arguments.
Naturally the arguments needs to be defined in the same order as the method expects them.

Now the aforementioned annotations work really well when you have access to the source code of the objects that you need to configure. But not if you want to add objects from a third party library. Or maybe you don't want to clutter your sources with framework specific metadata.

And that's it, when the configuration has been parsed, an object definition with id 'defaultAutowiringStageProcessor' will have been added with a class definition of 'DefaultAutowiringStageProcessor'.
This will set the resulting definition's lazyInit property to true and will register the definition with id 'processor' instead of 'defaultAutowiringStageProcessor'.

The difference with annotaing a property on a [Component] class is that you need to specify the property's name, whereas in the case of a [Component] class this is already implied by the property itself that has been annotated.

And that's, simple add properties for each object you need to be defined, and you're good to go. Just make sure that the configuration class gets compiled into your application by declaring it somewhere. You have to make sure of this since the class never gets instantiated.
You can add multiple classes that are annotated with the [Configuration] metadata, the object definitions will be aggregated.
